sections.content: Collection Paradise is a collection management tool that helps library workers make informed decisions about weeding, promotion, and item transfers through comprehensive statistical analysis.

content: We've expanded the traditional concept of weeding into a complete garden metaphor that encourages library workers to view their collections as living spaces requiring continuous care and cultivation. Just as the ancient Persian paradise gardens created ordered microcosms of knowledge and beauty, modern public libraries serve as curated spaces for community reflection and discovery.

Collection Paradise provides analysis tools that work at every scale—from your entire collection down to individual items—while also supporting display management and digital promotion across multiple channels.

Crop: A filtered list of collection items. You build crops on the 'Cultivate' screen by selecting your branch and collection type, then applying additional filters to generate your targeted item list. Manual crops can also be created on the Harvest screen by adding books by scanning barcodes or searching the database.
Cultivate: The screen where you create crops by filtering items based on your specific criteria.
Harvest: The page where you work with your crops—either pulling items for weeding, transfer, or display purposes, or generating promotional graphics for your website and social media channels.
Garden: Where your crops are stored, these are further grouped by category - 'weeding', 'transfer', 'to action' and 'complete'

sections.content: Begin by navigating to the Garden screen to view previously saved work or to Cultivate screen to create your first crop, then once your crop is saved, move to Harvest to put your curated collection to work. If you need inspiration, start with an overview of your collection on the Analyze screen.

content: The Analyse screen allows you to visualize a subset of your collection using a variety of charts and statistics.

You can select a library and a collection (or collection group) using the dropdowns at the top of the screen. The current number of available and on-loan items is displayed beneath the selection panel.
Selections are remembered between sessions, and default settings are loaded automatically unless overridden.
Chart data is generated based on your selected library and collection. Metrics are grouped and displayed in a series of chart panels. These include:
Library – Distribution of items among libraries
Collection – Distribution of items among collections
Collection Group – Collections rolled into higher-level groupings (e.g. Junior, Adult)
Status – Shows ON LOAN, AVAILABLE, MISSING, and ASSUMED LOST item totals
Age – Categorizes items based on age (years since creation)
Inactivity – Categorizes items by time since last activity
Circulation – Groups items based on total checkouts
You can switch between viewing total items, total checkouts, total price, or calculated metrics such as average price per item or price per checkout.
Each chart panel includes toggles to control which item statuses are included in the data:
Available
On Loan
Missing
Assumed Lost
Charts are interactive—tapping or clicking on a chart segment reveals a tooltip with detailed statistics, including checkout count, price, turnover, and date ranges.
You can also toggle individual categories on or off via the legend, allowing you to focus on specific parts of your collection.
The following chart types are available for each category:
Pie Chart – Visualizes the share of categories (e.g. collection types, item ages)
Bar Chart – Displays item count or checkouts as horizontal bars
Stacked Chart – Stacked bar chart showing included and excluded items
Scatter Plot – Plots category checkouts against total item count
Gantt (Activity) – Shows category durations based on item age or activity
Checkouts Bar Chart – Sorts categories by checkout volume for comparison
Use the chart view toggle to switch between these options. Tooltips and axis labels will update accordingly.

sections.content: The cultivate screen offers the same visualisation functionality as the Analyze screen but adds filtering and subsetting tools to identify and save a "crop" — a subset of items from the selected collection based on specified criteria.
These controls work the same as on the Analyze page. Select a library and/or collection to filter and analyze a specific group. You can also select grouped collections if configured.
Use the following panels to select a mode and configure filters specific to the chosen type. Each mode supports different search parameters.

content: Select a weeding type and use the slider to define a threshold. The following filter types are supported:
Grubby – Items with more than X checkouts (high usage).
Dead – Items not borrowed in the last X months (inactive).
Too Old – Items published more than X years ago.
DOA (Dead on Arrival) – Items published more than X years ago and never checked out.
Statistics such as age, inactivity, and checkout distributions are displayed to assist in selecting appropriate thresholds.
Search for items based on their status and inactivity:
Missing – Items marked as missing.
Claimed Returned – Items claimed returned by patrons.
In Transit – Items currently in transit between locations.
Use the inactivity slider to specify the minimum number of weeks since last checkout. You can select multiple statuses at once.
Set three filter sliders to define a complex query:
Items older than X years
Items with more than Y checkouts
Items not checked out in the last Z months
Only items meeting all three criteria will be included in results.

sections.content: Chart data for the selected filter is displayed similarly to the Analyze screen. You can toggle the Show Excluded option to view results both with and without non-matching items. Charts may include category breakdowns, collection groupings, and financial statistics such as average price and turnover.

Items matching the cultivation search are listed in the results panel. You can save these items as a crop, which will appear in the Harvest screen. Each crop can be reviewed, exported, or deleted as needed.
Use the Harvest screen to manage existing crops.
The Harvest screen allows you to view and refine a selected crop. Crops may be viewed as a list, gallery, or via charts, and refined through filters, selection tools, and sublists.

Use ISBN Lookup to fetch metadata and cover images from the Google Books API. If a match is found, the book's title, author, and description will be auto-filled, and the cover image updated accordingly.
Use filter to search within the current crop by title, author, or status. Results update in real-time and can help you isolate books for removal or sublisting.

content: Crops can be visualized in several modes:
Charts – Includes tabs for Activity (checkout trends), Distribution (status breakdown), and Checkouts (volume per category).
List – Shows book metadata, checkout history, and status (Found, Missing, Unknown). Items can be selected or edited directly from the list.
Gallery – Displays cover images in a responsive grid. Each item includes quick-access actions to update status or open the detail view.
You can toggle between views using the mode selector at the top of the screen.
To generate a sublist, or "crop":
1. Select items using checkboxes or tap Select All.
2. Tap Generate Sublist.
3. Enter a name for the new crop.
The new crop will be saved locally and become immediately available for review.
After creating a crop, additional books can be added manually:
1. Select the target library and collection group
2. Enter author and/or title keywords
3. Browse results and select books to add to the crop
Use the Approve button to confirm additions.
To add books via barcode:
1. Tap the Scanner button
2. Scan one or more barcodes
3. Review matched books
4. Tap Approve to add them to the current crop
Scanned items are matched by ISBN where possible and may fetch data via Google Books.
You can assign a crop image in two ways:
Upload from device – Select an image from your photo library or file browser
Generate collage – Choose up to 24 book covers from the crop to generate a branded image preview
Generated covers can be reviewed and re-generated as needed.

sections.content: Use the Garden screen to manage and organize your collections of crops.

Crops for the selected garden are grouped and displayed by source. Each group can be expanded to view the contained crops. Tap a crop to access additional actions such as rename, export, share, or delete.
Tap a crop, then choose "Export" to preview and export it in .txt, .csv, or .html format.
Tap "Create Manual Crop" to begin a new empty crop. You'll be redirected to the Harvest screen where you can add books via search or scanner.
Tap a crop, then choose "Share" to move or copy it to another garden. You can select the target garden and choose the mode (copy or move).
Tap a crop, then choose "Rename" to update its name. You'll be prompted to enter the new crop name.
Tap the pencil icon in the header to rename the current garden. Edits apply immediately after confirmation.
Tap "Change" to select a different garden from the list or create a new one.
From the garden selection menu, tap "Create New Garden" to start a new collection. You'll be prompted for a name and optional password protection.
If not protected, gardens can be deleted via the action menu. Protected gardens require password confirmation before deletion.
